title: exclusive eton leadership teetering edge farce former head english
story: Eton College's former head of English has warned that the school's leadership is teetering on the edge of farce.Joseph Francis, who taught at Eton for 20 years, said that the authority of both the head master and provost had been undermined by the free speech row that has engulfed the £42,500-a-year school for the past week.Mr Francis is the first former senior master to speak out publicly about the school's handling of the affair, and his intervention comes after a current master accused Eton of indoctrinating students.Last week, a row broke out after The  revealed that a master had been dismissed for gross misconduct after recording a lecture which questioned current radical feminist orthodoxy.The controversial lecture was part of the Perspectives course taken by sixth form students to encourage them to think critically about subjects of public debate.Will Knowland alleged that he was banned from delivering the lecture to pupils and then dismissed after he refused to remove a video of it from his personal YouTube channel.Eton has said the dismissal was not a matter of free speech but one of internal discipline. An internal panel, chaired by the school's vice-provost, will meet next week to consider Mr Knowland's appeal.But Mr Francis, who left Eton last year to set up a network of low-cost independent schools called Scholar 6, has warned that the outcome of the appeal panel will undermine Eton's head and provost whichever way it goes.Writing in The , he said: Knowland, with heavyweight support from two Harvard professors, has won key intellectual arguments.If his refusal to take down a video lecture about masculinity is deemed gross misconduct, he becomes a martyr to hundreds of boys, thousands of Old Etonians and millions of random bloggers. If the dismissal is overturned, Eton's leadership teeters on the edge of farce.Professor Steven Pinker, an expert in experimental cognitive psychology at Harvard University, has written to Eton's provost in support of Mr Knowland.In the name of honest and rigorous discussion of ideas, and respect for the ability of Eton students to evaluate and debate them, I urge you not to fire Mr Knowland, he said.Richard Wrangham Moore, a research professor of biological anthropology at Harvard, also wrote to Baron Waldegrave of North Hill saying he was astonished to learn of Mr Knowland’s dismissal.Prof Moore argued that the school's actions threatened Eton's reputation for openness, intellectual honesty, scholarly courage, and promotion of independent thought.Mr Francis, who used to be head master at Hampton Court House, said it was a mistake to insist that Mr Henderson remove the video.By instructing Knowland to withdraw his lecture, he undermined the principle of controversy behind the Perspectives course, he said. Knowland dug in and secured the higher ground.Former and current pupils have criticised Eton for dismissing Mr Knowland, with more than 2,000 signing a petition that accused the school of institutional bullying. But some parents have come to Mr Henderson's defence, saying that he has their total support and accusing Old Etonians of launching a smear campaign against him.Earlier this week, a current Eton master resigned one of his positions in protest and broke ranks to attack the school's indoctrination of students.Dr Luke Martin, who teaches Divinity at the 580-year-old institution, recently stood down from his role as the master in charge of Perspectives and said he was beginning to lose faith in Eton's ability to promote independent thinking among pupils.An Eton spokesman said: The school was advised by a specialist barrister that the content in Mr Knowland's video lecture – which appeared online with a reference to his employment at Eton – could very well breach a number of the school's policies as well as the school's legal and regulatory obligations. That gave the school no choice but to ask for it to be taken down. The school asked Mr Knowland to remove it, pending further discussion. He refused several requests to do so. A second lawyer conducted an independent investigation into his conduct, which led to a disciplinary hearing heard by a panel of senior teachers which did not include the head master. It determined that the teacher's actions represented gross misconduct which should result in dismissal. That decision is now the subject of an appeal.Many teachers have written to the provost or the head master supporting the line the school has taken. They have written in the belief that such correspondence is private.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: forget matt hancock obama vaccine poster boys really need
story: In unprecedented news, the crippingly publicity-shy Matt Hancock MP has volunteered to have the coronavirus vaccine live on television. Not because wants the attention, of course (or to jump to the head of an inoculation queue he’s otherwise not in) but to boost confidence in take-up of the PfizerBioNTech jab being rolled out here next week. Being ahead of Europe and America in greenlighting the jab has caused some skepticism, but it must be nice for the Government to get approval for something.And so, ever generous with his (air)time the Health Secretary has gone one further this time, agreeing to receive his first dose on Good Morning Britain alongside Piers Morgan . The race to become vaccine posterboy is not limited to British daytime TV, either: in the US George Bush, Bill Clinton and Barack Obama are offering up an ex-White House televised jab triptych.Perhaps all this public offering of flesh is a good thing the NHS was earlier this week rumoured to be compiling a list of “sensible” celebrities and influencers to convince the vaccine-hesitant, after all. If they really want to encourage people, the wan bingo wings of middle-aged politicians seems relatively unlikely to do it – especially when so many more compelling options abound. For example:Maureen from BarnsleyLike the Man from Delmonte and Jenny from the Block, 83 year-old Maureen – who earlier this year went viral after telling the BBC that she didn’t “give a sod” about impending Tier 3 restrictions – is iconic enough to have no need for a surname. Age-appropriate woman of the people? Sign her up.“What if every one of us was a raindrop?” “What is the point in bringing a new person into this world when they get to your age and it’s on fire?” (Nonsensical) questions for the ages posed by Prince Harry this week. Having him engage in something normal at this point would make for “good optics”, as LA-types say. And if he wants to get vaccinated in front of a backdrop of gently sloshing recycled rainwater, so be it.Along with Bigfoot and the Loch Ness monster, the quiet disappearance of Dr Jenny Harries OBE – you remember, the country’s deputy chief medical officer? Bob, glasses? – has become an unanswerable mystery. Where have they taken you, Jenny? Can you hear us where you are? The Government may think pandemic substitute Jonathan Van-Tam’s novelty ties are a fitting distraction, but no dice. At least the broadcast of her having the jab will cost less than the search party.This one would work competition style – highest bidder gets to stab Cummings in the arm live on national TV (screaming “THIS ONE’S FOR BARNARD CASTLE!” while so doing is optional). All money raised to go back into the shrivelling economy, and buying the man a new gilet.Along with “substantial meal”, “wet pub” and “new normal”, the Scotch egg has unfortunately become the latest two-word utterance rendered entirely unbearable from overuse. The only appropriate means of dealing with the fact civilisation has this week come down to a third rate picnic snack is by putting it together on-screen with the vaccine the force field emanating from the two greatest symbols of British freedom in one frame will be magnetic.Cases of Covid among twentysomethings have halved in recent weeks – the fastest age group to see such a drop (alongside those in their seventies). Which is good news, of course it is. Yet somehow feels crueller, on another all but locked-down weekend in which those of us in that tranche may still only mix with five friends or relatives on a sleet-covered park bench.There is no question that the most devastating effects of the pandemic have been on those who have lost lives, and livelihoods. But so much life has been lost, too – crystallised again during November’s restrictions, during which three of those closest to me celebrated their 30th birthdays. Looking back now, what we thought were dialled-down jollies in the summer – a barbecue for eight in August, then a rule-of-six pub gathering in September – now seem fanciful in the last three weeks I have watched one birthday girl grainily blowing out candles on Zoom, been sent a WhatsApp picture of the next receiving brownies I’d had sent, and last Saturday a quiet dinner for two, no friends, no fanfare. Losing these milestone moments doesn’t matter, I know, in the bigger picture. But it is still sad that the “roaring twenties” of so many continue to evaporate with a squeak. We’ll be living in a “different world by summer,” Boris Johnson promised a few days ago. Maybe next year, 31 will be the new 30.Grant Shapps charitably added no new countries to the travel corridor this week. But if you’d like to feel your mind transported as far away from reality as possible let us journey to Islamabad, where Cher has been busy securing freedom for the “world’s loneliest elephant.” After 35 years in confinement, Kavaan is now heading off to a new life in Cambodia following a balloon-strewn farewell ceremony, a diet plan that’s seen him shed 450kg in three months and primed to shack up with three lady elephants on arrival (by plane!) in his new 25,000 acre pad frankly, it feels as if Kavaan is having a better 2020 than the rest of us. Either way, good on him – and on Cher, for her surprise involvement in this pressing task. It’s not quite Dolly Parton funding the Moderna vaccine, but she’s done her hit.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: full search british hiker esther dingley could delayed spring
story: A full air and ground search for a missing British hiker could be delayed until snow set to cover the mountain this weekend has melted in the spring, officers hunting for her have admitted.Esther Dingley, 37, was reported missing by her partner, Dan Colegate, after failing to return from a solo walking trek in the Pyrenees on November 25.Her last message was via WhatsApp from on top of Pic de Sauvegarde, on the France-Spain border, three days earlier. Officers are treating the disappearance as a missing persons case and launched a desperate search operation for Ms Dingley, an Oxford graduate. However, the week-long search, involving helicopters, dogs and around 15 experts from several Civil Guard elite mountain rescue units, was halted on Thursday due to bad weather. The mystery threatened to deepen further on Saturday when a new witness came forward, claiming to have spotted Ms Dingley hiking up a mountain trail on the day she was last seen. Marti Vigo del Arco, a Spanish Olympic skier, told a Barcelona newspaper he and his girlfriend had seen the British hiker at around 3pm and thought it was late in the day to be climbing the Pic de Sauvegarde. It was just before 4pm that Ms Dingley had sent a selfie to her partner from the summit of the mountain.“She was coming up, we were on the descent, she was very heavily loaded with a very big backpack,” Mr Vigo del Arco told Spain’s La Vanguardia newspaper. “She asked us if we had a piece of fruit or something fresh, but we didn’t have anything,” said Vigo del Arco. “She carried on up.”The couple did not see anyone else coming up the mountain and may have been the last people to have seen Ms Dingley.Rescue teams have no plans to go out this weekend due to freezing temperatures affecting the peak from which Ms Dingley sent her last message, which is 8,983ft above sea level. They were also forced to abandon searching the village of Benasque, where she had left her car before embarking on the final leg of her journey.Sergeant Jorge Lopez Ramos, the head of the Civil Guard mountain rescue team in Benasque, admitted that the operation may not resume with the same intensity until next spring.He said: We appreciate the chances of finding Esther alive are minimal and it leaves us with a very bitter taste in our mouths. We have not found anything at all in any of the areas we've searched that might help us discover where Esther is.The weather has changed and the search finished on Thursday. In principle, if the adverse weather conditions continue as we expect, then we'll have to stop the search until we have a better idea of where we should be looking.The snow will cover the mountain and it's possible that it won't disappear until the spring. That means it's possible the search can't resume with the same intensity we've seen so far until the spring.Ms Dingley and Mr Colegate have been travelling around Europe in a van for six years after quitting their jobs and selling their home in Durham. Other Civil Guard units, including specialists in telecommunications, are believed to have been asked to investigate Ms Dingley's disappearance. Although they have remained tight-lipped about the work they are doing, they have privately dismissed the idea that she could have been attacked by a bear.They have made no comment on reports they are hunting a man travel blogger Esther said in her online travel diary had given her a lift down from the mountains in the days before she vanished.  More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: germanys prevarication huawei 5g bleak news free world
story: It’s a typical German solution which attempts to smother the difficult choices in complex procedures,” Martin Schallbruch, a former German official, told Noah Barkin of the German Marshall Fund this week. No, he wasn’t talking about Brexit, but about Germany’s decision on whether or not to let Huawei build its 5G network.After more than a year of prevaricating in an attempt to see off a powerful anti-Huawei alliance between her backbenchers and her coalition partners, Angela Merkel is ready to win in her usual way: obfuscate. According to Mr Barkin, Berlin’s almost-final policy proposal is now being circulated amongst its ministries and, in the words of an anonymous current official it “leaves everything wide open”.In effect, this is a victory for Beijing. The document details all sorts of procedures for what to do if various ministers can’t agree and vaguely tries to define untrustworthy suppliers, but ultimately resolves that if there isn’t a consensus, the status quo wins. In other words, Huawei stays.You can point out the hypocrisy of a country preaching about privacy rights and the transatlantic alliance while allowing a telecoms champion from a totalitarian country to build its communications infrastructure, but it doesn’t matter. German companies are, for the moment, still making too much money exporting to China for their government to risk upsetting the applecart. This is bleak news for the free world.On the bright side, it does make the UK look thoroughly decisive. This week, the government published its plans to phase out Huawei kit from September next year and incentivise the development of more alternative suppliers. One step at a time.Philip Green’s retail empire, which owns Topshop, went into administration this week. The Covid lockdowns were just the final straw for a business suffering from years of bullying leadership, under-investment and technophobia. Still, having grown up in the late 90s and early 2000s, I find it hard to compute that the mighty Topshop is fallen.For a teenage girl during the heyday of bands like the Libertines and Slipknot, Topshop was the definitive marker of hip. Its cavernous Oxford Circus store had the mysterious ability to turn “dowdy” into “retro” or “tacky” into “original”, cladding its skinny adolescent shoppers in flowery dresses and patent leather shoes, silk blouses, fake fur and fake lizard skin, leather jackets covered in zips, beaded vests dangling silver tassels, plastic bug-eye sunglasses, leopard-print headbands and garish jewellery.It was the shop that told you it was actually a good idea to buy cheap shoes off a hanger or don a felt trilby, to wear a faded SpongeBob SquarePants t-shirt with a gold sequinned miniskirt or to sport a pink tutu alongside huge army boots and a faux-military jacket. As someone who hardly dared to do any of these things and found the obligatory effort to haul on drainpipe jeans behind a flimsy curtain in its changing cubicles positively harrowing, its influence was frankly oppressive. But it was supreme.So now what? Someone will presumably buy the brand and hopefully save some of the 13,000 jobs at risk. But the old days are gone. Actually, I don’t miss them.“UK Says It Won Vaccine Race by Being a ‘Better Country’,” was the Bloomberg headline beamed around the world. Look, I’m all for politicians being patriotic, but the painfully half-smiling Mr Williamson doesn’t sound patriotic. He sounds like a semi-grown Draco Malfoy who went into politics and then realised he had to say things that might appeal to normal people.He has form, you see. In 2018, after the Skripal poisonings, he famously showed Putin who was boss by telling Russia to “shut up and go away”. Last year, sacked as defence secretary for allegedly leaking from a national security briefing, he claimed that he, like, seriously “did not” and we should believe him because “I swear on my children’s lives”.There’s a market for politicians who can encapsulate an everyman philosophy in a catchy phrase. Unfortunately for Mr Williamson, there is no compelling need for Cabinet ministers who boil everything down to a half-witted playground sulk. It’s high time the Education Secretary learned that if he has nothing coherent to say, he should say nothing at all.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: like brexit scottish independence lockdown has turned culture
story: This should be a moment when we come together in, if not exactly rejoicing, at least relief. We are weeks away from liberation. Britain has not always covered itself in glory over the past 10 months but, when it came to getting the vaccine, we brilliantly elbowed our way to the front of the queue. Phials of the antigen-inducing stuff are already in the country and, on Tuesday, we will become the first nation in the world to begin a mass inoculation programme.Already things are reopening. On Sunday, I will go to church, take my son to his rugby club and have lunch in the village pub – three things that were illegal a week ago. Yes, there are still irksome prohibitions, but we can glimpse normality around the corner. So why are we angrier than we were before?The answer, I think, has to do with the way almost every isive question now turns into a culture war. Two tribes, reading two sets of media, developing two unrelated narratives, subject to two opposed purity spirals, are so far apart that they might as well inhabit different dimensions.The imminence of vaccination ought, logically, to have put an end to our lockdown quarrels. Restrictions might end in January or February or even March. They might be phased out gradually or extinguished in one blow. But they are going. We no longer need to have furious arguments about the value of saving one life.That, though, is not how the political dynamic works these days. People might initially pick their side contingently and with reservations but, once they have done so, centrifugal forces haul them away from the middle ground. It happened over Scottish independence, it happened over Brexit and it has happened, too, over the lockdown.People who, in April, were mildly worried that the closures were disproportionate had, by October, begun to deny that there was any second wave, to decry facemasks as a symbol of servility, to dabble in anti-vax conspiracies. On the other side, those who had agreed, reluctantly and provisionally, to some restrictions, were now insisting that things stay closed until the entire country had been vaccinated.I find – again, just as with Brexit – that I have moved across the political spectrum without altering my views. I accepted that the lockdown would have some impact in slowing transmission, but I argued that the cost to liberty and livelihoods was too high. I wanted our default position to be freedom, and disliked the way in which defenders of the status quo, rather than proponents of radical change, were asked to prove their case. I particularly resented the way the goalposts kept shifting – the way “flatten the curve” became “beat the virus”.At first, my opinions upset lockdowners. Latterly, though, they have started to enrage the people who think that governments are too close to Big Pharma.In exactly the same way, arguing that we should withdraw from the EU’s political structures but keep many of its market arrangements, a position that defined me as an extreme Eurosceptic throughout the Nineties and the Noughties, nowadays makes me a wet in the eyes of some Brexiteers who have come late to the argument.Still, this needs to be spelt out. The immediacy of a vaccine alters the calculus. We are no longer being forced to put up with open-ended restrictions. We are no longer being told to suffer social and economic costs simply for the sake of pushing fatalities a few weeks into the future.The past ten months were a mistake, exacting too high a price for too slight a gain. But those ten months are now a sunk cost. The question is how to lift the remaining restrictions as early as practicable.Which brings us to the mirror radicalisation of the lockdowners. Had it been possible to vaccinate the vulnerable in March, there would have been no question of confining the general population.Now, though, the status quo has shifted, and with it people’s default expectations. I increasingly hear the argument that we shouldn’t end the lockdown until we reach herd immunity – in other words, until we have vaccinated some 70 per cent of the adult population.Starting with that conclusion, lockdown nostalgics then cast around for rationalisations. “Ah, but what about Long Covid – can’t be too careful, eh?”We need to be clear about this. Once people in at-risk categories have been offered the option of vaccination, the remaining restrictions should end entirely and immediately. We can’t stop people congregating because of a disease which does not pose an exceptional danger to the young or middle-aged. We must recover our ability to make reasoned assessments, to take calculated risks.Sadly, that is easier said than done. This week, the Deputy Chief Medical Officer, Jonathan Van-Tam, said that there wouldn’t come a moment when “we throw off masks and hand sanitiser and say that’s it, it’s behind us, like the end of the war”.Except that the end of the war did not mean the end of wartime controls. Identity cards lasted until 1952, rationing until 1954, conscription until 1960. This time, similarly, there will be pressure to make all sorts of emergency measures permanent. Will any future government be able to restrict free school meals to term time? Or withdraw the subsidies on which theatres now rely? Or defy pressure to give permanent preference to underprivileged exam applicants?If anyone can prevent the rise of a vast and malign nanny state, it is the prime minister, who immediately distanced himself from Prof Van-Tam’s remarks. Boris has the personality and the optimism to convince the country that there is nothing dangerous about the freedoms which, until this year, we regarded as our birthright. We need to hear his optimism now.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: covid 19 vaccine safe questions
story: AdvertorialIs it safe  Experts answer your biggest questions about the Covid- vaccineFrom side effects to safety, we ask the medical experts everything you want to know about the new Pfizer BioNTech Covid- vaccinemirrorShareByDave Masters:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC AdvertorialFollowing months of rigorous clinical trials, the Pfizer BioNTech Covid- vaccine has been approved for use in the UK by the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency. This and the other vaccines are a huge step forward in the fight against coronavirus and could save tens of thousands of lives. So is the vaccine safe  Who’ll get it first  And will it mean ato normal le  Our  of medical experts - made up of Deputy chief medical officer Professor Jonathan Van-Tam, Chief Executive of the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency Dr June Raine CBE and Head of Immunisations at Public Health England Dr Mary Ramsay - are here to answer all your questions...  Q. Vaccines usually take years to develop, so how can the Covid- vaccination be safeit’s ready in months  Professor Van-Tam: These vaccines have been through phase one, phase two and phase three, just like ordinary vaccines. With the Pfizer vaccine, I think the total clinical trial size is something like , the AstraZeneca results so far reported are based on just over , volunteers – there’s at least another , to follow, and the number size for Moderna is very similar. These are very, very big studies. The numbers involved were essentially the same as you’d expect for a normal peacetime vaccine, and on top of that the safety assessments and the assessments of effectiveness at the end are the same. Dr Raine: The public can be completely confident that Covid- vaccines will only be available once they have met robust standards of safety, quality and effectiveness. As Covid- is a public health emergency, scientic evaluation and approval is being done in the shortest time possible while complying with established and robust safety, quality and effectiveness standards. Extensive knowledge on vaccine development with existing vaccines is applied. Safety is our watchword. Everyone can be absolutely clear that the standards that need to be met, will be met. I am completely confident that there has been no pressure whatsoever on the agency and our expert staff to pass the vaccine. None at all. Q. How have you decided who gets the vaccine first  Dr Ramsay: We looked at a lot of data showing who was getting infection and who was dying from infection. The primary thing the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisationlooked at was death rates by age, by clinical factors, and by any other factors that GPs could measure, such as deprivation, geography or ethnicity. It’s very clear the death rate is much higher as you get older, particularly over . That’s why we’re prioritising people in older age groups, then coming down in age, picking up people who are clinically vulnerable and those who have underlying conditions along the way. Those working in health and social care will be high on the list as well – they are at risk because they’re getting exposed to infection every day and they may be spreading it to others. The same goes for care home workers – they’re a very high priority.  Q. Will the vaccine prevent disease or just reduce symptoms   Professor Van-Tam: If you’re going to prevent transmission you need a vaccine that is taking out the illness and also the asymptomatic infections. There are some signs from AstraZeneca that this might be the case. That does not mean the other vaccines where results have already been announced or that are or are still in development, don’t also reduce transmission it’s just we don’t know at this point in time. We hope they will because they’ll have a bigger effectthey can take out transmission. Q. Are there any side effects  Dr Ramsay: All the side effects are predictable – the kind of thing you get with other vaccines: a sore arm, bit of a temperature or feeling a bit fatigued, so we’re expecting it to have a similar safety profile to other vaccines. Professor Van-Tam: Every single vaccine authorised for use in the UK has been authorised by the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency . The three components of authorisation are a safety assessment, an effectiveness assessment and a manufacturing quality assessment – all three need to be ticked before anything is authorised. But there is not a single medicine without side effects. Is it possible that rare side effects could come to light that you’d never pick up in a clinical trial of ,-, patients  Yes, it is – but that’s no dferent from any other medicine.  Q. How will the vaccine be rolled out  Dr Ramsay: The actual act of giving the injection isn’t particularly skillful – all nurses are trained and most vaccines are given by nurses, but with the flu jab we use health care assistants. The key thing is they work under the supervision of nurses. I think there’s going to be a lot of dferent models used because, for example, with elderly, frail people they’re clearly not going to drive to the nearest centre – you might have to take vaccine to them in their home. The hospitals will probably be doing their staff, then there will potentially be these vaccination sites which will probably be more important for the slightly younger population who can drive there. Q. Is there anyone who shouldn’t have it   Dr Ramsay: A reason to defer a vaccination is being pregnant – that’s just being precautionary. We don’t expect there to be a problem, but without having the vaccine tested on pregnant women we’ll probably recommend they wait until after they’ve had the baby. Similarly, it hasn’t been tested in children, although a teenager would probably respond similarly to a young adult so they could likely have the vaccine. Q. Will it be available privately  Professor Van-Tam: I don’t know, but I think it would be a bad thing for public healththe rich and privileged were able to pay their way to the front of the queue, leaving someone at very high risk and not wealthy low down the list – and they would be there’s going to be a global shortage of these vaccines. So I’m opposed to that. Q. How long will it take to immunise as many people as is needed for us toto normal le

title: im spending christmas total silence
story: NewsIm spending my Christmas in total silence with a complete strangerSherylin Thompson wont be spending Christmas Day with her family opening presents this year - instead shell be going away to spend it on a silence retreatmirrorShareCommentsBySherylin Thompson:,  DEC NewsSherylin has now been on  silent retreats - and this year will be her sixth at Christmas" %, rgba, rgba, url"Join the Secret Elves to discover the best shopping deals and things to do this ChristmasSpread the Christmas cheer!When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThis year I’m spending Christmas in silence. Complete silence. There’ll be no cards, no presents, no crackers or trimmings – not even a glass of fizz. In fact, on Christmas Day, itself, I’ll be waking up next to a stranger. As crazy as it may sound, I can’t wait.I had no idea what meditation was until I went to Thailand in . I’d separated from my husband after four years of marriage and went away to do some soul-searching.One day I went on a trip with a group of people to a beautul temple and we were askedwe would like to do meditation. I was the only volunteer.  The monk got me to sit in the lotus position, which was terribly painful, then asked me to close my eyes and to see a flame in front of me and focus on my breath.All I could think about was how sore my knees were and what I’d be having for dinner. I couldn’t wait for it to end. It went on for two hours, but when I walked out afterwards, I felt amazing. My senses were heightened, I felt so aware and alert and relaxed. It was incredible. I was training in psychology and interested in how the mind worked so, back in London, I found a meditation class and started going once a week. I bought meditation CDs and books and even a cushion so I could practise at home. I got so into it, my mother became concerned. She thought I was conversing with spirits, trying to become a medium or something.My parents are strong churchgoers and had no idea about meditation. They thought it could be dangerous and affect my mind. But the more I practised, the more I could feel myself benefiting. It helped me understand myself and my relationships better, it helped me come to terms with my orce.I can be quite self-critical and it helped me to be less harsh on myself and learn to manage those critical thoughts better. I felt calmer. I wanted to immerse myself in it more fully so, that year, I went on a Christmas retreat.I’d spent the previous Christmas partying with friends, so spending it in silence couldn’t be more dferent. I didn’t tell my parents or my friends or work colleagues. I thought they’d think I’d become some kind of crazy hippy and it was all a bit weird. I was almost ashamed of it. The retreat was at a Quaker school in Oxfordshire and fairly basic. I was told to bring comfy clothes and slippers. The dormitories were in outbuildings and quite cold. I was relieved to get a room to myself.  But the biggest challenge was the silence. It was a beginner’s retreat for  days so they introduced it gradually – a couple of hours a day, then half a day, then a full day. I still found it dficult. The fact it was Christmas made it harder.I was glad I’d taken a book and spent most of the time reading, then I found out you’re not supposed to read, you’re supposed to avoid all communication, including reading, eye contact and smiling. It’s all about “stilling the mind”. I was tempted to send a text, but I tried to respect the silence because you don’t have that in ordinary le – it’s rare. Everyone was allocated a task – chopping vegetables or washing up, sometimes cleaning the toilet. In between meditation , we got on with our tasks. Of course there is no speaking, so the tasks were listed for us to see on a notice board.Christmas Day was just like any other day. There were no decorations, carols or trimmings. We had a nut roast for dinner and sat in silence.I found it strange at first. It felt rude to be sitting down with no one talking – eating is such a social thing.But after a couple of days, my mind began to slow down and settle and I actually found it quite nice. It took the pressure off making conversation and I could enjoy the food more.It was the same routine every day – we got woken by the bell at am, we did meditation before breakfast, then got on with our tasks. Then, after sitting or walking meditation in the grounds, it was time for lunch. The food was vegetarian or vegan – simple, but good. Always freshly prepared and it smelled lovely. There was no alcohol. I enjoy a glass of wine, but I didn’t miss it.Katy Perry, Jenner Aniston, Madonna and Angelina Jolie have all spoken about the benefits of meditation. Silent retreats were among the top wellness trends for  and often attract people aged  to . Retreats offer the chance to rest, reflect and reconnect with nature, do yoga, swim, walk or simply nap. Prices in the UK y from £ for a weekend to between £ and £ for  days.

They treated him worse than an animal.” Michael, who lived alone in Wythenshawe, Manchester, became ­distressed as he made his way to see his brother Andrew and cut his hands while breaking windows on June , . Two officers called to the scene said he appeared aggressive and they feared he may have attacked someone because of his bloodied hands, the High Court was told. One constable squirted CS spray twice while his colleague used his Taser twice, with one shock fired while Michael was on the ground despite there being enough officers to physically restrain him. PC Samuel Schofield then arrived and discharged his Taser twice, delivering eight shocks lasting  seconds over a period of  seconds before Michael was taken to hospital. Official advice is not to use a Taser after CS spray has been deployed because it may be flammable. Tasers should also not be usedthey have already proved ineffective. Michael was taken to Wythenshawe Hospital and later diagnosed with PTSD. Retired social worker Novlyn said: “He wasn’t able to communicate at all. It was horrendous.”

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAuthorities have launched an investigation after a stretch of Hertfordshire river important to wildle was bulldozed. The works were labelled a tragedy after the mile-long stretch of a protected riveraposs banks was flattened. The Herefordshire Wildle Trustsaid it hopes for a prosecution over the damage to the River Lugg, which it called a crime against the environment. The trust said all bankside and riverside habitats have been completely obliterated after the river and its banks were bulldozed, straightened and reprofiled into a sterile canal. A potato and cattle farmer has come forward claiming he cleared the land to prevent flooding at nearby properties.However experts have claimed the works will make flooding worse downstream and put wildle at risk. Farmer John Price, , claimed local homeowners had become frustrated waiting for authorities to tackle the blocked river after their homes were damaged in last yearaposs floods. So he had taken matters into his own hands, he told The . Mr Price, whose farm neighbours the river on a farm in Kingsland, near Leominster, admitted to the newspaper he had bulldozed and cut trees down - but claimed he acted with permission from local authorities.  He said he had watched the river all his le, claiming no one knows this river better than myself. I have always looked after the river. He also claimed he had the support of the village and parish council, and had been asked to stop the erosion because he was the land owner adjoining that stretch of the river. Mr Price told The : It was up to the Environmental Agency to look after these rivers but they donapost do any work and havenapost got any money to do the work because they spend it all on clipboards. He added: I have not pushed any trees out and I havenapost knocked any trees down I have only cleared what ones came down in the flood.  The Environment Agencysaid it had launched an urgent investigation. West Mercia Police confirmed the force is assisting the probe. The HWT said wildle affected by the damage includes crayfish, otters and salmon, lampreys and dragonflies and a host of rare river wildle at the Site of Special Scientic Interest. The trust said the River Lugg would be a test case for the Governmentaposs commitment to strengthen wildle protection, and it hopes for a prosecution. HWT chief executive Helen Stace said: A large stretch of one of the UKaposs most important rivers, the Lugg, has been devastated, with dire consequences for wildle and water quality downstream - this is a tragedy.  The bankside trees are all grubbed out and burnt, the river gravels have been scraped away, and the beautul meanders of the river have been straightened and reprofiled. As former leader of the English Nature rivers team which notied the Lugg as a Site of Special Scientic Interest, I know this river to be one of the most enchanting tree-lined reaches, with immense value for wildle. This is a crime against the environment. Swt action needs to be taken and we want to see the authorities investigate the matter swtly. We expect this case to be dealt with in a serious and robust manner and any resulting prosecution should act as a deterrent to prevent anyone committing this type of crime ever again.  We will also be calling for restoration of the river to its natural channel. HWT said it believes bulldozing part of the river is a contravention of the Wildle and Countryside Act and the Environmental Permitting Regulations  and should have required consent from the Environment Agency, as well as planning consent. Craig Bennett, chief executive of The Wildle Trusts, said: The Government has promised to transform our environmental governance as we leave the EU and for the UK to be a world leader in environmental protection. Devastating incidents such as this one will be a vital apostest caseapos as we come to the end of the transition period for the Governmentaposs ambition to develop a aposworld-leadingapos environment enforcement structure.  Unfortunately, the Government has so far failed to live up to this standard, with poor resourcing leaving Natural England unable to properly monitor and protect our most important wild places - Sites of Special Scientic Interest. Andrew Nixon, conservation senior manager of HWT, said: The actions taken on this stretch of the river will have far-reaching consequences, both for this stretch of river and floodplain and further downstream. story: NewsGangland assassin "The Iceman" made victim dance like cowboy by firing at feetEXCLUSIVE Mark Fellows has finally admitted how he carried out two executions as part of a tit-for-tat Manchester gun war between groups known as the “A Team” and the “Anti-A Team”mirrorShareCommentsByDan Warburton:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsMark Fellows fired bullets at a rivals feet to make him dance like a cowboy before killing him" %, rgba, rgba, url"Our free email newsletter sends you the biggest headlines from news, sport and showbizWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAn assassin known as The Iceman has finally spilled the beans on two executions that landed him in jail until his dying day. Mark Fellows showered a hail of bullets on gangland rivals but never explained how or why. Now the Sunday Mirror can reveal he has finally admitted his guilt over the Salford drug wars that earned Manchester the title “Gunchester”. In letters from jail, sickening Fellows tells how he:Hid in a graveyard wearing a fake beard and a mask until “Mr Big” Paul Massey came home. Fired bullets at Massey’s feet so he “danced like a cowboy” before firing the fatal shots. Joked about killing a PC who nearly interrupted a stakeout. Shot Massey’s mob fixer John Kinsella as he walked through woodland – finishing him off as “he lay crying on the floor”. Wants to die from cancer rather than serve decades in London’s tough Belmarsh jail. Is prepared to kill again in prison – knowing that his sentence cannot be increased. The hits were the bloody culmination of a tit-for-tat drug war between Massey’s “A Team” and the “Anti-A Team”. Fellows, , tells all in letters due to be published in the true crime book Salford Lads. He reveals how, night after night, he lay hidden in a churchyard with an Uzi submachine gun waiting for the perfect moment to kill Massey, . And he even laughs as he tells how he considered killing a cop. Fellows writes: “The night before I was waiting for Massey and a police officer turned up when I was laying there. “I thought that I was going to have to do him but he never saw me. Ha ha ha!”  It was .pm on July , , when Fellows pulled the Uzi from a bag and fired round after round at Massey. Fellows says that despite the  beard, mask and being clad in combat fatigues, Massey still spotted him as he stepped from his Series  BMW. A murder trial at Liverpool Crown Court was told  rounds were fired – four hitting Massey’s chest. Fellows pleaded not guilty to two murders but was convicted. Now he explains in grisly detail just what happened. Of Massey, a grandfather, he writes: “I parked my van in the estate, my bike was in the back. I had my mountain bike gear on. I rode to near Paul Massey’s house and put my bike in the bushes. I got to the church, changed into the army gear and put a  beard on. I was laying in the churchyard, Massey’s house in front of me.  “[Massey] saw me, so I shot at him from across the road, but missed. When I crossed over, he was behind the bins, hiding. I was playing games with him, shooting at his feet like they do in cowboy films. “That’s why he got shot in his foot and that’s why so many bullets were fired. He tried to make it to his front door, so I put one in his chest. He hit the floor, out cold. I didn’t want to get close, so stood back and shot four times at his head. “I missed and my clip had run out, so I made my way home. If I’d have got close... I’d have hit his head and he wouldn’t have been able to make any phone calls, but at least he is dead.” The murder trial heard a  call made by Massey. He said: “Ambulance. I’ve been shot... hurry up”. The operator asked the postcode – then the line went silent. Massey made his name selling drugs in Man-chester’s s rave scene and was a known “face” in Salford.  Meanwhile, Kinsella, , was respected and feared in equal measure and famously intervened when a gangster threatened “to maim” former Liverpool and England footballer Steven Gerrard, . Fellows was said to be a trusted foot soldier in the so-called Anti-A team. The gang feud – which as recently as last year spilled over to the Costa del Sol – is thought to have begun when a woman threw a drink over a member of the A Team in summer . Violence quickly escalated. A shotgun was fired into a car, injuring one man, before another victim suffered horric injuries in a machete attack. In March  a grenade was thrown at an A Team family member’s house. Months later Christian Hickey, seven, and his mother Jayne were shot and injured at their home. The picture of Christian in a hospital bed shocked the nation. He was left in a wheelchair and needed a string of operations to be able to walk again.  His dad, Christian Hickey Snr, had been the intended target. Fellows – nicknamed Iceman for being cold and calculated – was already in the frame for Massey’s murder when he shot Kinsella in May . The victim was walking in woods in Rainhill, Merseyside, with his partner. In one of his letters, Fellows says: “Kinsella was lying on floor so I put another one in him to shut him up... then I put two in his head.” Kinsella – who had a six-week-old baby – was considered a small-time player but the killings were strikingly alike. Detectives found a Garmin watch Fellows used for long-distance running. It recorded him on a reconnaissance run shortly before Massey’s killing. The data correlated with the hundreds of hours of CCTV and phone records analysed by police. Fellows was found guilty in February  of murdering Massey and Kinsella. He is one of only  UK people to get whole le terms. Co-defendant Steven Boyle, , was found guilty of the murder of Kinsella, but cleared over Massey’s killing. He was jailed for le and will serve a minimum of  years. Last month Fellows was handed another le sentence for his part in a machete attack on Aaron Williams, an associate of the A Team gang. Police found £, in Fellows’ house, thought to be his assassin’s fee .

He spent days transforming his home into a spooky Halloween house covered in skeletons and tarantulas in October. This year Danny and his family have spent the last few weeks turning the house into a winter spectacular to try and spread some festive cheer and raise some money for charity by doing so. Being a busy time of year, Danny said they were often adding items late at night so you can imagine the neighboursapos shock when a huge helicopter appeared in the garden one morning.  The film lover owns a special effects company called Real SFX who are responsible for creating the special effects in shows such as Doctor Who and Peaky Blinders. The Grinch is behind the wheel of the crashed helicopter in yet another attempt to steal Christmas, while the mischievous Gremlins are scurrying around the house. Danny said he usually tries to go away for the festive period but as that hasnapost been able to happen this year he decided to do more decorating than usual. I initially thought about having Santa crash the helicopter but thought that would look a bit odd so in the end I thought aposwho would be mischievous enough to crash a plane apos and it just had to be the Grinch. While Danny and his partner have been decorating the house in some form each year, this year they decided to raise money for charity by doing so. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailTerried neighbours described the harrowing moment they saw someone jump out the window engulfed in flames when an explosion near their home caused two people to be seriously injured.Residents in Illingworth, West Yorkshire, said they thought there had been an earthquake near their home when a house collapsed following an explosion that could be heard three miles away.Police said a woman was taken to hospital with severe burn injuries as was a man who suffered serious injuries. Another female received minor injuries in the incident. Local resident and mum-of-two Candice Nevison, , said she thought her own house had collapsed for how loud the bang on Green Lane was. She described how one person jumped out their window engulfed in flames following the explosion at around : on Saturday. Another person ran out of the burning building, said Ms Nevison, whose own mother was among those safely evacuated. It sounded like there was a massive bang and it felt like something had fallen on my head, she said. The impact was just so extreme I thought my own house was collapsing. I was terried because it was so loud and my mum lived right on that street.I looked out and there was a massive fire. Thankfully my mum was evacuated as one of the six homes and sheaposs okay. She added: I saw people running out the house at around .am. I saw one person jump out the window while another person carried an old lady over her shoulder. You just donapost expect anything like this to happen. Iaposve never seen or heard anything like it before. Another neighbour described the massive blast as surreal. He was told that three people in the property were taken to hospital with burns.  Colin Stone, , said: I just got out because I thought my house had exploded. The whole street thought so - it was surreal. We were told by fire marshalls that they got taken to hospital with burns, I hope theyaposre okay. West Yorkshire Fire and Rescue service manager Benjy Bush said they were not ruling out the possibility that a gas leak may have caused the explosion. But he said it was too early to determine and efforts were focused on securing the area after extensive and signicant damage caused by the blast and subsequent fire.  More than  firefighters along with four fire engines, support and specialist teams attended the scene. Mr Bush said that an elderly lady as well as two others who were in the house were being looked after by a neighbour after they escaped from the collapsing building when they arrived. The extent of their injuries is still unknown, but they are currently recovering in hospital. Mr Bush added: We donapost know yet what caused the fire.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Queen and Prince Philip could receive the coronavirus vaccine within weeks, reports claim.However the senior royals will aposwait in lineapos for their turn and wonapost get preferential treatment, according to the Mail on Sunday. Pfizer and BioNTechaposs jab has arrived in the UK and will begin being rolled out to the public within days.The clinically vulnerable and frontline health care workers are at the head of the queue for the long-awaiting coronavirus vaccine.Sources told the newspaper the Queen, , and the Duke of Edinburgh, , will be eligible within weeks and have already accepted the offer of the jab. Both are reportedly expected to accept the offer based on the advice of their doctors. They will be in line for the jab once people in their s and care home residents are offered it. The elderly are among the top tiers of the priority queue for the Covid- vaccine. The most severely clinically vulnerable people with listed medical conditions will be given the first shots. Public health experts are said to be considering whether publicising the senior royalsapos vaccinations will help their campaign to combat anti-vaxxer sentiment.  Prince Charles and Prince William are also reportedly being considered for roles in publicising the vaccination programme.  However the Mail reports such a move could be seen as Buckingham Palace allowing the royals to be politicised. Courtiers are also said to be concerned there could be concerns about breaching the royalsapos medical privacy.  The younger royals, including Prince William and Kate Middleton, wonapost be in line for the jab until later in  when it is expected people in their thirties will begin being vaccinated. The Mail reports that the possibility of the royals playing a role in vaccine promotion to allay scepticism is being discussed at Buckingham Palace and in Whitehall. Officials are also said to be considering whether widely respected celebrities such as Sir David Attenborough could be asked to front-foot the campaign by getting the jab. However officials are said to be concerned about provoking allegations of favouritism. A spokeswoman for Buckingham Palace said that medical decisions were personal, and they would not be commenting on the story.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThis week we got the news that we have all been waiting for. The first Covid- vaccine has been approved for use in the UK. It is now here and ready to be rolled out. I’m hugely grateful to all the ­scientists around the world who have made this happen. They have worked non-stop – just like our frontline healthcare professionals – to put a halt to this virus and let us get on with le as normal. All of those who volunteered for the vaccine trials deserve a huge thank you for helping to make this ­happen so swtly. Without all of you, we would not be where we are today. Developing a vaccine for coronavirus is a huge achievement. And it’s important people are ­reassured that these treatments have been rigorously tested before being licensed for use. As a society, we take so many medications daily without question. How many of us get the annual flu jab  I certainly do, working in our NHS. We all simply trust they will make us feel better and stop us getting ill. That is because our independent regulators work hard to trial vaccines and drugs to ensure they’re safe. That’s no dferent for this vaccine. Thousands of the smartest minds across the world have been working to develop a vaccine. That is why we have so many prospects on the horizon. It’s important to recognise that these experts know more about the science of vaccines than random people on social media do. In recent years, the spread of misinformation has increased dramatically. It’s vital the Government launches a large-scale public information campaign to answer questions on the vaccine and encourage uptake.  Dangerous myths circulate on social media and it’s not good enough to just ignore them and hope they go away. Labour has offered to work with ministers to tackle online harms, and that’s why we’re calling on the Government to bring forward their long-overdue Online Harms legislation because we need a regulator with real teeth to cope with social media companies. If the vaccine is good enough for all the scientists and the regulator, then it’s good enough for me and my family. Too many lives have been lost from this virus. The UK passed the tragic milestone of , deaths from Covid- this week. Each of these , people has a family struggling with the reality of grief during Covid-. These are all lives lost too soon.

The Queen invited the new Duchess of Sussex to join her for a day of engagements in Chester, and they travelled there together on the train. In their book Finding Freedom, royal reporters Omid Scobie and Carolyn Durand describe Meghanaposs trip on the train. They write: It was a daunting journey for the new we, despite the amenities of Her Majestyaposs personal train, which had private bedroomsa sitting room with a sofa of hand-stitched velvet cushions, a dining table for six, a desk where the Queen worked on her papers and secondary air suspension for a smoother than average ride.The train conductor drives extra slowly around .am to make sure the water stays in the tub while the Queen has her bath. The Royal Train has been used by Monarchs since Queen Victoria, and while it used to be just as plush as you would expect, with bright velvet sofas and cushions, itaposs now far more low key with simple decor and furniture. The train has bedrooms, bathrooms, a sitting room and a large dining room, and there is also an office where the Queen works during her travels.The train also has space for her staff, and there are bedrooms with bunk beds. Speaking to the BBC back in , director of royal travel Tim Hewlett said: There is a perception the train is a bit like the Orient Express. But there are not many bathroom furnishings you could not get in Homebase or BQ. Queen Victoria was the first monarch to travel by train, and her favourite carriage on the old steam train has recently been restored to itaposs former glory.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA teenager who had initially thought he was tired due to grieving his granddadaposs death was told he actually had cancer. University of Chester student Ben Thornton was diagnosed with testicular cancer aged just . Doctors told him it had spread to his liver, lungs and brain in just  hours. He received the devastating diagnosis just days after attending his grandfatheraposs funeral. Ben has recalled the day two years ago he saw his GP about feeling lethargic.The doctor immediately recognised something was seriously wrong and sent him to AE, reports Cheshire Live.After running some tests, doctors told Ben that they suspected he had cancer in his lungs. He was then taken to intensive care, where it was discovered that the cancer had started in his testicles and had spread. Ben said: “I’d just started my second year of university and went back home to Bristol for my granddad’s funeral. I was feeling lethargic, but I just put it down to the fact that I was going through an emotional time. As the week went on I started feeling a bit fluey and sick, I remember sitting in the church during the funeral and feeling queasy. “When I got back home to Chester I saw a GP, who told me I looked really dehydrated and should go to AE. I could barely walk at this point so got a mate to drive me there – but even walking from the car to the hospital entrance was a struggle and I had to lean on the wall to recover.” He started emergency chemotherapy right away and had to stay in the ICU for about three weeks. Once he was well enough, he was transferred to Clatterbridge Hospital, where he was supported by Teenage Cancer Trust’s specialist nurses.Ben was in treatment over Christmas , and worried that he would not make it home for Christmas Day.He explains: “It was touch and go as to whether Iaposd be allowed home for Christmas – but on Christmas Eve I managed to convince them to let me go.I managed to have a big Christmas dinner and fitted in a snooze afterwards to wake myself back up. We still had fun as a family, and I played new Xbox games with my siblings like we usually would.”Shortly after Christmas, Ben was transferred to a Teenage Cancer Trust unit in Bristol to be closer to his family. He finished chemotherapy in April , and then went through two surgeries: one to remove two lymph nodes on his liver, and one to remove his right testicle.Ben is now in remission, but the coronavirus crisis has made  another challenging year.He explains: “There are some benign tumours left in my lungs and I’m asthmatic, so I could be more at risk. We’d planned to go to Australia this year but thataposs now had to be cancelled – I was seeing it as a big trip to celebrate getting back to normal. This year’s really been put on hold.” Now aged , Ben is backing a new campaign from charity Teenage Cancer Trust - and has a message of hope and sound advice for people young and old this Christmas who are facing cancer treatment during the coronavirus pandemic. He adds: “My advice to people going through treatment at this time of year is to really throw yourself into Christmas! Christmas is a great opportunity to forget about treatment, so try not to spend it worrying about what’s ahead. And most importantly, eat as much as you can!” Coronavirus has had a severe impact on Teenage Cancer Trust’s income, slashing it by a third – a shortfall of around £million a year. Yet due to the pandemic, support from its specialist nurses and youth workers is needed more than ever, which is why Ben is sharing his story in support of the charity’s Christmas fundraising appeal. Kate Collins, Chief Executive at Teenage Cancer Trust, said: “Sadly, young people with cancer have been hit harder than most by the coronavirus pandemic.

The two women, both part of huge crime families in the north of England, were caught on camera doing a cash for drugs deal. Natalie Wrafter, , and Shazia Din, , were filmed in the car park of Doncaster prison after visiting Wrafteraposs kingpin father, Peter. Peter had led the Doncaster side of a huge cross-Pennines drug trafficking operation from December  to the following July, reports the Manchester Evening News. The Wrafters were involved in the supply of class-A drugs, including heroin and cocaine, with Natalie taking over the family business when Peter went to prison. Police found Peter in possession of a revolver and ammunition, alongside a kilo of heroin which was kept in a van outside his Doncaster home - he was sentenced to -years for his part in the operation which had seen him join forces with another crime family from Bury, Greater Manchester. This Greater Manchester crime family was led by Din who, alongside her sister, Abia, , distributed heroin, cocaine and amphetamines throughout South Yorkshire-based networks. In the clip that was secretly filmed in the car park of HMP Doncaster, Wrafter can be seen passing bundles of cash to Din, who stuffs them into a bag in the boot of her Mercedes. After the money was handed over, James Dickson travelled from Doncaster to Manchester to conclude the trade deal struck by Natalie Wrafter and Din, the Manchester Evening News reports.  A beauty business, known as aposThe Beauty Boothapos was set up by the Din family as a front to launder dirty money made from vast profits, police say. Din, of The Drive, Bury, is now serving a  year jail sentence after pleading guilty to conspiracy to supply class A drugs, namely cocaine and heroin, and MDMA and conspiracy to supply class B drugs, namely cannabis and conspiracy to convert and transfer criminal property. Natalie Wrafter, of Harewood Avenue, Doncaster, who pleaded guilty before trial to conspiracy to supply class A drugs, namely cocaine and heroin conspiracy to supply class B drugs, namely amphetamine and conspriacy to convert and transfer criminal property was jailed for  years three months. Dickson, , of Fojambe Crescent, Doncaster, was convicted by a jury of conspiracy to supply class A drugs, namely cocaine and heroin and was jailed for four years six months. Another member of the drugs ring was snared after a police pursuit, also caught on film. Graham Towriss, whose role was a courier, was stopped on the A northbound in Doncaster by traffic officers after suppling a kilo of class to Mark Bird in a gym car park. A few weeks later Towriss was detained in Doncaster after a police chase during which he threw a kilo block of cocaine from his vehicle.  He was found to be in possession of an encrypted phone and worked for the Din family - he had previously been seen by covert officers meeting Hassan Din, in the Rochdale area. He was Shazia Dinaposs son, who played a key part in the drugs operation, along with her sister, Abia. Towriss, , of Hartford Avenue, Heywood, was convicted in September of possessing cocaine with intent to supply possessing heroin with intent to supply possessing a controlled drug of Class A with intent to supply possessing cannabis with intent to supply driving when unfit through drink or drugs and dangerous driving. He was jailed for six years. Bird, , of Stonegate Mews, Doncaster, was convicted by a jury of conspiracy to supply class A drugs, namely cocaine and heroin and jailed for seven years. Hassan Din, of The Drive, Bury, was jailed for  years. He pleaded guilty to conspiracy to supply class B drugs, namely cannabis, and conspiracy to transfer criminal property. He was convicted by a jury of conspiracy to supply class A drugs, namely cocaine and heroin and conspiracy to supply class A drugs, namely MDMA. A third piece of footage captured David Wright travelling from Rochdale to a housing estate in Doncaster with a block of high purity cocaine in the passenger footwell of his vehicle. Melvyn Sheldon was filmed running from the vehicle before being caught by police officers. Wright was found in possession of an an encrypted phone and had previously transported £, in criminal cash for the Din family.  The cocaine was recovered and had a wholesale value of £, due to its purity. Wright, , of Fletcher Close, Heywood, who pleaded guilty to supply class A drugs, namely cocaine, and heroin, and conspiracy to convert and transfer criminal property was jailed for four years. Sheldon, , of East Avenue, Doncaster, was convicted by a jury of conspiracy to supply class A drugs, namely cocaine and heroin and jailed for six years. In total  people were jailed for a total of  years for their part in the drugs ring. Over  kilos of class A drugs including heroin and cocaine worth £m were seized, £, in cash a hydraulic press, drugs paraphernalia, a handgun and ammunition following Operation Heart conducted by GMP and South Yorkshire Police. Detective Inspector Lee Grfin, of GMP’s Serious and Organised Crime Group, said: “During the operation we scrutinised this group intensely as we uncovered their illicit activities across the country, enabling us to gather evidence and unravel the conspiracy.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailFor the first time since the pandemic struck we have been given a reason for hope. From this week the first doses of the Pfizer vaccine will start to be administered. It will be a le-changing moment for those living under the darkest clouds of Covid. It means people who have been shielding will finally be able to leave their homes. It means families can be reunited, care home visits can be made without fear, and frontline health workers can be protected. In the long run, it offers the opportunity for le toto normal so we can wave goodbye to the days of social distancing. But vaccinations only workthe majority of people take them. As deputy chief medical officer Prof Jonathan Van-Tam has warned, a low uptake of the jabs will almost certainly mean the restrictions will have to last longer. Some people have concerns about the safety of the new vaccines. This is partly because of the misleading information about inoculation that has been allowed to swirl unchecked across social media. But it is also because of a lack of faith in this government. That is why we should applaud celebrities who stepped forward to endorse the jab. By setting an example they will encourage more people to get vaccinated which, in turn, will help us contain the virus. The fact this paper has turned to A-listers for help in getting this message across is a damning reflection on the low standing of ministers.  It is a consequence of Boris Johnson lazily raising expectations and offering  hopes. He told us in July that le couldto normal by Christmas. It didn’t. He told us we could soonto offices and workplaces. We didn’t. He told us that a second lockdown in England was avoidable. It wasn’t. When public trust has never been more essential for the good of the country, the Prime Minister has squandered it. Cruellest cut Months of Covid restrictions have taken a terrible toll on people’s mental health across the whole nation. So it is inexplicable – not to say disgraceful – that the Government has decided to cut funding for the Time to Change charity. For years the Sunday Mirror has been proud to work with this brilliant organisation to raise awareness of mental health issues.

title: russia starts rolling out coronavirus
story: NewsRussia starts rolling out coronavirus vaccine with teachers and doctors at front of queueMoscow began distributing the Covid jab on Saturday via  clinics in the first large-scale vaccination - the UK will begin vaccinating people on Tuesday with a path out of the pandemic now finally in sightmirrorShareCommentsByJeremy CulleyAssistant Editor:,  DEC NewsA nurse gives a patient the Covid jab in Moscow " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailRussia began vaccinating people against coronavirus on Saturday. People in Moscow could receive the jab at  clinics, with teachers, doctors, medical staff and social workers first in line.The cityaposs coronavirus task force confirmed the Sputnik V vaccine was now being deployed.You are working at an educational institution and have top-priority for the COVID- vaccine, free of charge, read a phone text message received by a school teacher early on Saturday. President Vladimir Putin has ordered a nationwide voluntary vaccination programme to begin next week. He said Russia will have produced two million vaccine doses within the next few days.The head of the Russian Direct Investment Fund , Kirill Dmitriev, said in an interview with the BBC on Friday that Russia expects to give the vaccine to about two millionpeople this month.Over the first five hours, , people signed up for the jab - teachers, doctors, social workers, those who are today risking their health and lives the most, Mayor Sergei Sobyanin wrote on his personal website on Friday. Russia has already vaccinated more than , high-risk people, Health Minister Mikhail Murashko said earlier this week during a separate presentation to the United Nations about Sputnik V.  Among the first people signing up to the Moscow roll-out, Nadezhda Ragulina, an administrator at a Moscow clinic, said she wanted the vaccine as she had witnessed many COVID- patients. This is my decision... Some people close to me also have had an experience , she said. Thataposs why I want to protect myself, my relatives, to obtain the immunity, she told Rossiya- state TV channel. Moscow, a city of around  million people, has been the epicentre of Russiaaposs coronavirus outbreak. It reported , new cases on Saturday , up from , the day before and well above the daily tallies of around  seen in early September. The age for those receiving shots is capped at . People with certain underlying health conditions, pregnant women and those who have had a respiratory illness for the past two weeks are barred from vaccination.  Russia has developed two COVID- vaccines, Sputnik V which is backed by the Russian Direct Investment Fund and another developed by Siberiaaposs Vector Institute, with final trials for both yet to be completed.Scientists have raised concerns about the speed at which Russia has worked, giving the regulatory go-ahead for its vaccines and launching mass vaccinations before full trials totest its safety and efficacy had been completed.The Sputnik V vaccine is administered in two injections, with the second dose is expected to be given  days after the first. The UK is the first major western power to approve a vaccine for rollout, with the jab to start being made available to the most at risk on Tuesday.  Scientists in Europe and the US appeared to cast some doubt over Britainaposs regulatory processes, although the UK bodies insist no corners were cut. Russian Deputy Prime Minister Tatiana Golikova said on Friday that the vaccinated should avoid public places and reduce their intake of medicine and alcohol, which could suppress the immune system, within the first  days after the first jab. Moscow closed down all public places including parks and cafes, with exception for delivery, in late March, with police patrolling the streets looking for whose violating the rules.

title: coronavirus first supplies of covid 19 vaccine arrive in scotland
story: The first supplies of the new Covid- vaccine have arrived in Scotland.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon confirmed the news in a post on Twitter.She said: #Some positive news # initial supplies of the Covid vaccine have now arrived safely in Scotland and are being stored securely. The first vaccinations are on track to be administered on Tuesday.#mdash Nicola SturgeonDecember , Over the next few months the aim is to distribute the vaccine to more than four million adults across the country with those most in need getting the treatment first.Those charged with giving the vaccine to others will be the first to receive the course, which requires two doses between  and  days apart.At a daily briefing last week, Nicola Sturgeon said she would be prepared to get the Covid vaccine on live televisionshe thought it would persuade others to get it.The news comes after the Scottish Government confirmed a further  people have died after testing positive for the virus.The daily update also showed there have been  new positive cases confirmed in the past  hours.Britain’s medical authorities approved the rollout of the Pfizer and BioNTech Covid- vaccine on Wednesday morning, paving the way for vaccination to start next week.The jab has been shown in studies to be % effective and works in all age groups.Health secretary Jeanne Freeman told the BBC: #I am pleased to announce that the vaccine is now in Scotland and being stored safely in order for vaccinations to begin on Tuesday. Science has given us hope and we are starting on a journey which will eventually allow us to escape this terrible virus.#Following clinical advice from the joint committee on vaccination and immunisationwe will begin with those groups which have been prioritised to address % of preventable deaths associated with Covid-. title: dundee fc dundee united james mcpake calum woodger column
story: I’m sick of sounding like a broken record but James McPake really needs to start getting a tune out of his stuttering Dees today.Last week in this column, I said I feared the project ‘James McPake – Dundee manager’ was failing and failing fast.However, he and his side showed they might just prove me wrong with an improved display against Hibs, albeit bowing out of the Betfred Cup following a - defeat at Easter Road.There were signs that maybe, just maybe, he could still turn things around.Not picking up all three points against Arbroath in the league today, however, and my story is back on.See what I mean about a broken record Dundee boss James McPake says recent weeks have been toughest time of his footballing career" title"#Dundee boss James McPake says recent weeks have been toughest time of his footballing career# # Evening " src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp dundee-boss-james-mcpake-says-recent-weeks-have-been-toughest-time-of-his-footballing-career embed # like the Hibees, but Arbroath at home is an entirely dferent thing altogether.That kind of outcome just won’t do for the Dark Blues, I’m afraid.They must win at Dens today, it’s as simple as that.Eventhey weren’t in their current slide, that would be the expectation among the Dee support, unable to voice their all-apparent discontent in person at the moment.Given their current circumstances, not even a draw and another good display would do for under-fire boss McPake and struggling his side, in my opinion.Anything other than victory, all three points and progress up the Championship table, at long last, should leave the Dundee hierarchy seriously questioning how they move forward.I sincerely hope that is not the case, though.Genuinely, I am willing McPake on to, finally, get things right after so long threatening to do so.Hopefully, he can get the Dark Blues dancing to the same beat and back in a rhythm before long.Finding that groove won’t be easy, that’s been the story of the -year-old’s whole tenure, but there are promising signs the Dee have finally found some kind of settled line-up after being dogged by injuries and Covid.If he can get the men he trusts to deliver for him on the park against the Red Lichties today, there’s no reason why they can’t overturn Dick Campbell’s side.After all, Arbroath have hardly set the heather alight this term, in stark contrast to taking the league by storm the previous campaign.Of course, they, like many others in this tough second tier, always pose a danger, but Dundee can’t afford to think too much about the opposition when so much is at stake in terms of their own situations this afternoon.They have to get the turntable that is their season and their gaffer’s reign spinning again.Quite simply because you can blow fluff out of the needle all you like but , your vinyl is scratched beyond repair, it’s maybe time to get a new record and find a sound you’re happy with.Losing the nucleus of a successful crew to Covid- isolation couldn’t have come at a worse time for a Dundee United ship that was sailing along smoothly.Minus Micky Mellon, his back-room team and nine first-team players for  days, what Courts, taking control of the first team, and it is clear it will require effort from other background figures to pull the club through this.Let’s just hope whoever is out s minus the cabin fever!With
