title: Leisure facilties stay closed to curb Covid
story: A NUMBER of sports, leisure and community facilities across the district will remain closed as part of the latest coronavirus measures introduced by the Northern Ireland Executive.Newry, Mourne and Down Council has confirmed that the ious facilities are scheduled to remain closed until December  as part of a province-wide move to help reduce the spread of the virus.In Downpatrick, the Down Leisure and Ballymote sports centres are closed, as is the Newcastle Centre. All local authority pavilions and changing rooms, classes, sports halls and multi-purpose rooms in all leisure and sports facilities are also closed, but some community centres remain n open but will operate on a restrictive basis.Centres which focus on the provision of childcare and library services are among those that remain open to the public, with council officials working with existing hirers to facilitate necessary community activity that has been robustly considered and risk assessed.Elsewhere, all recreational and group swimming tuition has ceased, while outdoor sports facilities, including tennis courts and bowling facilities, grass and articial pitches, are closed. All council play parks remain open with visitors asked to adhere to social distancing guidelines.Council officials have confirmed that they are seeking further clarication on a number of the new restrictions which will be reviewed in light of any further changes to the regulations.The local authority said it may make changes as it receives further clarication on the restrictions and to allow a timescale for implementation.Council officials say they appreciate that this is a very worrying time for its customers and all members will be given the appropriate discounts or extensions to their memberships. They will be contacted by email with more information.Downpatrick area councillor Dermot Curran said while people will be disappointed that so many sport and leisure facilities have closed, the important thing was to adhere to social distancing guidelines when out about visiting council facilities that are open.The local retail sector has also been hit by the latest lockdown restrictions with Cllr Curran asking people to support the districtrsquos business sector. He said doing so this year is more important than ever.ldquoMany sporting organisations have been hit hard by lockdown restrictions and given that sport is so popular across the entire district the closure of leisure centres and sports facilities and pitches will impact a great many people, he said.ldquoAt this moment in time we need to do all we can to keep ourselves and others safe. I also hope that in the final few weeks before Christmas people will support our local business community but remember to shop safety and adhere to social distancing measures.Meanwhile, anyone wishing to speak with a council official about a membership package or who has other queries is asked to telephone   .The council has confirmed that will also continue to provide latest information and updates via the NMD Be Active App, NMD Be Active Facebook page and its website https:www.newrymournedown.org leisure-facilities..prettyPhoto

title: Minister urged to commit funding to begin bypass
story: STORMONT roads minister Nichola Mallon has been asked to commit the money required to build Ballynahinchrsquos new multi-million pound bypass.The appeal was made at special meeting of Newry, Mourne and Down Council on Monday evening when roads officials tabled their annual report detailing planned investment across the district during the current financial year.The meeting took place just weeks after it emerged that a start date for the near two-mile bypass could be revealed early in the New Year.Mrs Mallon has confirmed that she will make a so-called direction order within weeks which is expected to outline when contractors could be on site.Major progress has been made over recent years to advance the scheme to link the Newcastle and Saintfield roads with the bypass designed to alleviate chronic town centre congestion in Ballynahinch and along the main approach roads to the town.Major new roundabouts are proposed at the Belfast Road junction with the Saintfield Road and at the Newcastle Road junction with the Downpatrick Road, with a new bridge constructed over the Moss Road.Overtaking lanes stretching almost  metres are proposed at either end of the bypass where the major new roundabouts are to be constructed, with the scheme also including a shared footpath and cycle lane.The bypass is the single biggest road scheme ever proposed for the district with suggestions that it will take at least  months to construct, with roads officials insisting that the scheme will reduce journey times and improve road safety.Last June, the roads minister included the bypass in a list of strategic projects expected to progress during the current financial year, with the local scheme mdash which could cost up to poundm mdash effectively ready to proceed.At the time, roads officials said the bypass was now at an ldquoadvanced stage of development and that preparatory work on contract documentation had been completed.Officials said the roads minister had asked them to complete the work necessary to allow her to make the so-called direction order which included reviewing environmental reports which is nearing completion.The government department said that subject to the outcome of the review, the minister hopes to be in position to make the direction order for the Ballynahinch bypass in the New Year and was committed to moving ahead with the scheme.On Monday evening, Rowallane councillor Billy Walker said while progress on the eagerly-awaited scheme is welcome, what people want to see is money committed to allow contractors to begin work.ldquoConfirmation that the roads minister is preparing to make a direction order is good news. Progress is at last being made, but the money required to finance the scheme is the final piece in the development jigsaw, he said.ldquoThis scheme is good news for the people of Ballynahinch and the wider district and what everyone is keen to see is a timetable for delivery.Cllr Walker said the bypass had been talked about for  years and was now literally within touching distance.He added: ldquoWhat we require is a definitive timetable and confirmation from the roads minister that the money to build the new road is there. The scheme is finally moving in the right direction and now is the time to commit the money to ensure its delivery.Cllr Terry Andrews also welcomed progress in the bypass which he said can make a signicant dference for not only Ballynahinch, but the wider East and South Down areas.Rowallane councillor, Robert Burgess, said people in Ballynahinch look forward to the delivery of the scheme, urging consideration be given to farmers whose land has ben set aside for  years to accommodate the planned bypass.ldquoThese farmers have been unable to do anything with these areas of land which will probably be vested. The situation they fund themselves in is not fair, he added.The Department for Infrastructurersquos network manager, James Kelly, said while a previous roads manager was minded to proceed with the Ballynahinch scheme, it did not reach the point of going ahead.He said there was now an opportunity for roads officials to refresh the schemersquos environmental assessments before presenting them to the minister again.Mr Kelly said with the scheme expected to cost between poundm and poundm,Mrs Mallon wishes for it to proceed, the bypass will have to enter a process where it will be competing for finance with other schemes.He added: ldquoWe cannot guarantee that the money will be available next year..prettyPhoto

title: New bus at Knockevin Special School following £28k donation
story: KNOCKEVIN Special School in Downpatrick has taken charge of a new bus thanks to the generosity of the Lordrsquos Taverners and the schoolrsquos parent staff association.The PSA donated pound, towards the cost of the new wheelchair accessible bus which was provided by the Lordrsquos Taverners, which provides support for people with disabilities.The bus was recently handed over to the school by PSA members, who will also fund its running costs.The PSA was formed in  when parents and staff came together to fund music therapy for the pupils which was no longer being funded by the relevant authorities.The associationrsquos goal is to support all of the pupils at Knockevin Special School in Downpatrick and Knockevin Early Years Centre in Dundrum.PSA chairperson Kelley OrsquoReilly said: ldquoSince we formed we have raised considerable amounts of money through ious events and projects, such as the Sparkle Project in , with our previous chairperson Paula Dillon at the helm, which saw the local community come together to raise money for the refurbishment of two sensory rooms and the hydrotherapy pool.ldquoWe smashed our target of pound, to raise a staggering amount of over pound, and we were able to provide the school with a bicycle track and new bikes.ldquoWe funded a Memory Tree, which the school had wanted for some considerable time, designed and constructed by local artist Kevin Killen, to remember pupils who passed away while attending Knockevin.Kelley added: ldquoWe also have recently agreed to fund the refurbishment of the soft play area in the Profound and Multiple Learning Disabilities unit within the Downpatrick school site. Our next aim is to provide funding for outdoor gym play equipment which is essential at this time.Due to the Covid pandemic the PSA was forced to cancel or postpone many fundraising events such as the annual  and k runs and family fun walk.The bag pack at the Asda supermarket Downpatrick also had to be cancelled, although the PSA received a generous donation from Asda for its Christmas raffle.The tenth anniversary ball, which was to have been held in the Burrendale Hotel, has been put back until October .A drive-in movie screening of the Christmas film Elf at Letrsquos Go Hydro in Carryduff this Sunday has also been cancelled, but there are hopes that it can be rescheduled for a later date.Said Kelley: ldquoWe are always so grateful of all the support we receive not only from our parents, carers and school staff, who all volunteer their time to organise and carry out events, but also the local community.ldquoWithout everyonersquos help we would not be able to continue to support our amazing children and young adults, which is our purpose.She added: ldquoBoth school sites are held in such high regard by the local community and by parents and carers.ldquoWe look forward to a time when we can resume fundraising as a community again. As the school motto says mdash together we can achieve more..prettyPhoto

title: No Stone Unturned journalists receive huge payout from PSNI
story: TWO journalists who were arrested over material that appeared in the No Stone Unturned documentary on the murder of six men at OrsquoToolersquos Bar in Loughinisland in  are to receivesignicant damages from the PSNI.It is understood that the PSNI has also agreed tomaterial it seized from Trevor Birney and Barry McCaffrey after they raided their homes and offices in August .The PSNI has agreed to payout pound,, including pound, to Fine Point Films which made the documentary, and pound, and pound, paid to Mr Birney and Mr McCaffrey respectively.News that a settlement had been reached was announced during a brief hearing at Belfast High Court last Friday morning.The two journalists were arrested over the alleged theft of a police watchdog document that appeared in No Stone Unturned produced by the Belfast based production company and directed by Oscar winner, Alex Gibney.The documentary centres on the notorious loyalist massacre in Loughinisland when six Catholic men were murdered while watching a Wold Cup football match on television involving the Republic of Ireland and Italy.The men who died were Adrian Rogan , Malcolm Jenkinson , Barney Green , Daniel McCreanor , Patrick OrsquoHareand Eamon Byrne . Five others were also wounded in the sectarian attack.Northern Irelandrsquos Lord Chief Justice, Sir Declan Morgan, welcomed the fact a settlement had been reached between the parties.ldquoWe congratulate the parties on finding an answer to this interesting and dficult, but also important case, he told lawyers in Belfast High Court.Last year, Sir Declan and other senior judges ruled search warrants used by police to search the journalistsrsquo home and their offices at Fine Point Films had been ldquoinappropriate, resulting in the criminal probe into Mr Birney and Mr McCaffrey being discontinued.The original police operation had been undertaken by Durham Constabulary at the request of the PSNI amid conflict of interest concerns.In the summer Chief Constable Simon Byrne issued an unreserved apology to the two men.Reacting to the settlement, Mr Birney said it marked an end to the legal process he began in a police cell at the end of August  after being arrested and his home and offices raided by dozens of PSNI and Durham police.ldquoWe launched a Judicial Review in the face of the PSNIrsquos most egregious attack on journalism to protect our journalism, our sources, and press freedom itself, he said.ldquoOver the past two years, thePSNI fought our attempts to protect our journalism and sources every step of the way.ldquoThey sought to defend their indefensible attack on press freedom right up until the judgment delivered by the Lord Chief Justice in July this year.Mr Birney said he and Mr McCaffrey have welcomed the Chief Constablersquos apology, but said no such apology has been received by Mr Byrnersquos predecessor, Sir George Hamilton, under whose leadership the PSNI arrested the two journalists.Mr Birney added: ldquoJournalists in this jurisdiction now need to see Simon Byrne take all steps necessary to ensure accountability for the PSNIrsquos despicable attack on press freedom and to assure the press that lessons have been learned..prettyPhoto

story: As a subscriber, you are shown % lessThose ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local servicesThese adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityTHE solicitor spearheading legal action against the Northern Ireland Executive on the continued prohibition of childrenrsquos outdoor sports has called on parents, clubs and young people to share their experiences, all of which will be included in a pending legal challenge to same.Stephen Atherton, of J.J. McNally Solicitors, has issued a pre-action notice advising he will seek a Judicial Review,necessary.The Executive overshot the notice deadline, and while it has since been confirmed a response will be issued by Tuesday, December , Mr. Atherton branded this: ldquoA cynical attempt to frustrate due process.Mr. Atherton said: ldquoIn March, the lives of our children were turned upside down.ldquoThe cruel and bitter irony is, however, that it is not the Covid- virus that is harming our children ndash it is societyrsquos response to the pandemic that is damaging the physical and mental health of the youngest and most vulnerable members of our community.ldquoThe Executiversquos failure to respond meaningfully thus far has inhibited my ability to lodge proceedings in the High Court, as it will not countenance making an order against the Executive in the absence of any substantive response from them, particularly in circumstances where they have indicated a date of reply.He claimed: ldquoThis is a cynical and deliberate attempt to frustrate due process, and will result in children being unable to play sport outside in any context this weekend.ldquoWhen this correspondence arrives, its adequacy will be considered and, unless the Executive relents and permit a swtto play, I will move immediately to enforce the rights of children and give them a voice.ldquoThus far, no one has been prepared to protect them, added Mr. Atherton.On the back of numerous responses supporting the campaign, Mr. Atherton is now calling for anyone wishing to share their experiences of how the prohibition is impacting on children, ldquoto get in touch.He said: ldquoI am giving a commitment to lay all experiences shared with me before the Executive, andneed be, the High Court, to ensure children and their families have a voice.ldquoIt is incumbent on any society and all decision-makers to ensure children are listened to, and their concerns appropriately considered and addressed.ldquoThe groundswell of support from the public from right across the country and beyond is overwhelming.ldquoIn response to some negative commentary, I wish to advise I am pursuing this without payment.ldquoI am a parent myself, andI can do something which can only benefit children and young people by giving them a voice, that is more than payment, in my eyes.This website and title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % lessThose ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local servicesThese adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. story: Finucane killing: Dodds lists eight terror attacks linked to other legal figures that get little attention   Inside the self-deception an unrepentant killer needs to stay sane – but at what price  Ex-UVF man Billy Hutchinson admits: My le is full of contradictionsNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutChristmasCarsHomes and GardensCoronavirusFarmingPuzzlesChristmasPublic NoticesNewsPoliticsBen Lowry: Archbishop Welby has been played for a fool in talks, which raise questions for DUPIt hardly needs be said that churchmen should go to places morally and politically that few others will.By Ben LowrySaturday, th December , : pmUpdated Saturday, th December , : pm  "       "  "it is a deep betrayal of the UK government to allow the Northern Ireland Office to be in these secret talks, along with the organisation to which the NIO defers, Ireland’s Department of Foreign Affairs, but without any critics of the Stormont House Agreement on legacySuch open mindedness is at the heart of Christianity.So it is not a surprise that the Archbishop of Canterbury has involved himself in the thorny issue of Northern Ireland’s legacy.The problem is that the secret Lambeth Palace talks have excluded all sceptics of the legacy process who think it unbalanced against state forces.   " fill"#ea"  to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...In doing so this trend perpetuates a trend of ignoring such voices going back to , and this newspaper’s Stop the Legacy Scandal essays.The series was open to anyone who thought legacy was being handled in such an unbalanced way as to be a scandal. Beyond that contributors wrote what they wanted and there was a wide range of essays.We ran articles from an ‘official’ republican Padraig Yeates, from the ex IRA man Shane Paul O’Doherty, from the churchmen Canon Ian Ellis and Rev Alan Irwin, from ex security force personnel such as Alan McQuillan and Col Tim CollinsThere were essays from victims campaigners such as Kenny Donaldson, from politicians such as Doug Beattie and Jim Allister, from commentators such as Kevin Myers and Ruth Dudley Edwards.We ran essays from victims such as Anne Grahamand Jackie Nicholland Anthony O’Reilly .There were essays from the lawyers including the barrister Austen Morgan and the solicitor Neil Faris and academics such as Liam Kennedy and Henry Patterson. The legacy scandal series did not take a position on the  Stormont House proposed legacy structures, but anyone who read all the essays would agree that that plan took a battering. Many writers thought Stormont House would not resolve the advantage the IRA has on legacy, and might even worsen it.Yet since that series such scepticism has continued to be largely ignored. There have been many legacy discussions on radio or TV which only included supporters of Stormont House.By far the largest number of Troubles victims were murdered by republicans . Some victims of such terror back Stormont House, but increasing numbers of them do not.So when you hear a legacy broadcast that includes an IRA victim alongside republicans and others, it might seem balanced but it isn’tthe victim is pro Stormont House. If so, then it is a discussion among people who agree.The Archbishop of Canterbury has presided over talks that does not include those who believe legacy is demonising state forces who prevented civil war.Six elderly soldiers are proceeding to homicide trials for single shooting incidents half a century ago while no IRA leader who orchestrated decades of murder is.Every time an imbalance in these prosecutions is alleged a host of voices emerge to ‘prove’ not The legacy scandal is far greater than soldier prosecutions, but the veteran element to legacy is at least easy to understand. Did Most Rev Justin Welby not pause to askany IRA leader faces trial  Why terror godfathers such as Brian Keenan, Kevin McKenna, Billy McKee, Martin McGuinness never served time commensurate with their boodshed. They were allowed to come off violence, after decades of it, at a time of their choosing, then to live out their days with no fear of arrest.Did Archbishop Welby not wonder why the former victim commissioner Judith Thompson lost the faith of many victims  Did it not occur to him to research the dference in outlook between victims groups such as WAVE and Kenny Donaldson of the large Innocent Victims United umbrella group, the latter of which has persistently protested that legacy is being soft on terrorists Did it not occur to him that retired police, representing ex RUC, were not present in his talks, but army concerns were present, and this might be because army have greater clout  .Did it occur to him that people in his talks might be trying to depict IRA and state forces as equally culpable for the past violence  Because such voices are widespread.If anyone is still trying to understand what is happening on legacy, then here is a simple way to explain it: Republicans and their growing army of apologists are not remotely scared of legacy. They know the UK has not the heart even to contradict their lies, let alone chase them through the courts in the way republicans are being allowed to chase the state.Archbishop Welby has bedn played for a fool. But it is a deep betrayal of the UK government to let the Northern Ireland Office be in these secret talks, along with the organisation to which the NIO typically defers, Ireland’s Department of Foreign Affairs. Radio Ulster this week let that perpetual scold of the UK, Ireland’s foreign minister Simon Coveney, sermonise atand with minimal contradiction on the need for yet more scrutiny of the appalling murder of Pat Finucane. No wonder Dublin feels free to hector London on legacy. The latter has said nothing as Ireland has humiliated the UK before the Council of Europe for not doing enough on legacy cases that the IRA holds dear. A contemptible failure of Stormont House was that it did not seek to investigate Ireland’s security failures, including decades of extradition refusals so that fanatical IRA killers were able to base themselves there .When the UK naively signed the  Anglo Irish Agreement they thought this would improve. It didn’t.Earlier this year London realised its blunder at Stormont House. But I never believed there was much to its retreat. All they want is to keep down costs and avoid soldier prosecutions. The reported presence of the MoD, but no RUC representatives, is proof of that .Evenan amnesty leads to an end to prosecutions, the republican goal is clear: demonise the state through sub criminal investigations.They are happythey get endless inquiries that are decided on a civil standard of balance of probabilities, not a criminal one of beyond all reasonable doubt. It is why they pushed for a Finucane inquiry to add to the legacy inquests, which have become mini inquiries into allegations against the state.Peter Robinson in his News Letter column on Friday  wrote powerfully on what a grievous injustice it would be to spend yet millions more on this one Troubles killing.But he ended on a troubling note calling for “an agreed victim-centred framework for investigations”.That sounds good but the DUP under him agreed Stormont House. It prompts the question. What is the position of the DUP on these talks  It is astonishing the party was not given even a hint of them. So now, given what we know about the imbalance in participants and the complete exclusion of sceptics, the party could be clear and state that it will treat any recommendations from this process with the contempt they deserve.• Ben Lowryis News Letter deputy editor• Ben Lowry: There is a grave imbalance in the number of soldier Troubles legacy prosecutions• Peter Robinson: To hold an inquiry into the murder of Pat Finucane while ignoring thousands of others would be an outrage——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityClaire Danter and India Danter have teamed up to produce Nelson#s Funfair Holtspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtliday lt spangtlt spangt" Funfair mum Claire Danter combats PTSD with children#s book writingClaire Danter and India Danter have used their experiences in their book#s pltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtroductionlt spangtlt spangt" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentA MUM from a travelling funfair family has traded on her experience of post-traumatic stress disorderto produce a childrenrsquos book available from Waterstones and Amazon.Claire Danter, writing under the name of Claire Carey, wrote Nelsons Funfair Holiday more than a year ago, having turned to writing as a form of therapy after she was attacked.Mrs Danter, , and husband James and sons James Jnr and Jonathan were part of the reopening of Barry Island Pleasure Park in  and stayed for three seasons.Her niece India Danter, who has illustrated the book, was born in Newport, moved to Caldicot and grew up on the funfair travelling around South Wales with her parents at Caldicot, Abergavenny, Cwmbran, Newport, and Cardf.Pleasure Park owners hit with order to stop calling ferris wheel the "Barry Eye"Barry Islands Ferris Wheel under threat due to planning disputePleasure Park rides due on site in three weeksMrs Danter said: ldquoMy journey to becoming a writer is the classic story of turning negative into positive.ldquoI started writing just after I suffered an attack - it was an unexpected vicious attack by another woman.ldquoAfter the attack I started to suffer from PTSD.ldquoI visited my doctor many times, how could I have PTSD ldquoI hadnt been to the front line.ldquoMy doctor told me it only takes one traumatic event or one moment when you believe your le could be lost.ldquoThe mental burden of PTSD is dreadful.ldquoI wouldnt wish that on anybody.ldquoIt has taken me over two years of my le to get to somewhere near normal and even now Im not the same person I was.ldquoThe writing was the escape I needed.ldquoWriting has aided my recovery so far and I would recommend this to anyone suffering from PTSD.ldquoAlthough Im left with the scars of PTSD, itrsquos is behind me now.ldquoWriting has now become a hobby for me and the sense of achievement - holding a published book in your hands that you have written is the best feeling.ldquoItrsquos great.Mrs Danter drew inspiration from a childrenrsquos book which she personally found horrying.ldquoI saw a childrens book called Dex and the Funfair by Paul Shipton.ldquoIn my opinion the story is shocking.ldquoEvenI wasnt part of the funfair industry myself, I wouldnt want my children to read such a book.ldquoThe worst part about this, is the book is fact that it is in some school libraries.The book details Dex smashing up a tin can alley stall and the stallholder giving Dex a prize to make him leave.ldquoThis is shocking on all levels, she said. ldquoAllowing children to read books like this at the age of five or six cannot be a good thing.ldquoMy second inspiration came when my nephew came on holiday with while we were on our travels, which in turn reminded me just how much fun it was growing up on the fairground.ldquoI decided to write Nelsons Funfair Holiday - a story about a little boy who goes to stay with his auntie who owns a funfair.ldquoThis story will give children a glimpse of what it is like visiting and growing up on the fairground.ldquoChildren in my opinion must have all the experiences le has to offer to broaden their minds ready for the wider world.ldquoTravelling fairgrounds are part of our heritage in the UK and across Europe.ldquoItrsquos our history, its who we are and we are all play a part in that, whether you grow up on the fairground or not.The Danters originally hail from Brynmawr.Goff Danter, an artist, was able to offer India tips and advice on illustrating the book which is her first having previously been commissioned to do pencil drawings under the trade name Romayne Art.Mrs Danter also has another book under her belt.Entitled Me and My Social Media, itrsquos a short, gripping story about the dark side of social media and how a perfectly normal family can be turned upside down.ldquoI am very proud of this book, she added. ldquoEverybody who reads it tells me they cannot put it until they have finished it.Nelsons Funfair Holiday costs pound. and is available from Amazon and Waterstones. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. ldquoThis has been a very long and dficult year for everyone."All our lives have been turned upside down by the coronavirus pandemic.ldquoEveryone has done so much to help control the spread of the virus and to save lives."But that has meant many sacrices, including not seeing family and close friends."We are all looking forward to Christmas and a chance to spend some time with all those we hold dear.ldquoToday, I met the First Ministers of Scotland and Northern Ireland and Michael Gove, from the UK Government, and Irsquom pleased we were able to agree a common four-nation plan for the festive period.MORE STORIESWhat you need to know about Cardf Bus Christmas travelHow to help brighten up Christmas on Barry Island boatsWho now qualies for  per cent off Morrisons groceries The text, of a joint statement issued by the four UK governments, said: As  draws to a close, we recognise it has been an incredibly dficult year for us all.We have all had to make signicant sacrices in our everyday lives, and many religious and community groups have already had to change or forgo their customary celebrations to slow the spread of coronavirus and save lives.This cannot be a lsquonormalrsquo Christmas.But as we approach the festive period, we have been working closely together to find a way for family and friends to see each other, evenit is for a short time, and recognising that it must be both limited and cautious.Even where it is within the rules, meeting with friends and family over Christmas will be a personal judgement for iniduals to take, mindful of the risks to themselves and others, particularly those who are vulnerable.We need everyone to think carefully about what they do during this period, balancing some increased social contact with the need to keep the risk of increased transmission of the virus as low as possible.This is particularly important when considering those who are vulnerable, and before deciding to come together over the festive period we urge the consideration of alternative approaches such as the use of technology or meeting outside.In this context, the four administrations have reached agreement on a single set of UK-wide measures to help people come together with their loved ones in a way that is as safe as possible.Today we have agreed that:bull Travel restrictions across the four administrations and between tiers will be lted to provide a window for households to come together between December  and December.bull Up to three households can form an exclusive lsquobubblersquo to meet at home during this period. When a bubble is formed it is fixed, and must not be changed or extended further at any point.bull Each Christmas bubble can meet at home, at a place of worship or an outdoor public place, but existing, more restrictive rules on hospitality and meeting in other venues will be maintained throughout this period.It is important that everyone respects and abides by the rules of each nation wherever they choose to spend the festive period.Where there are any iations in our approach, these will be communicated by each administration accordingly.Further guidance will be provided in due course.The winter holiday period is a time often spent with family and friends, with schools and offices closing and people travelling over the bank holidays.Many have already begun making their plans, and we are today providing clarity to help people make the right choices for them, and enjoy time with those closest to them while staying within the rules to protect us all. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: findings review penarth streets linked slavery
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityClive Place, Clive Crescent, and the Clive Arms Hotel were all deemed in the green category, meaning ldquopersons of interest are not commemorated.The review advises that while the names are associated with colonist Lord Robert Clive, they do not commemorate him.Plassey Street, which had been marked as another potential link to slavery, was not included in the audit review.The report was commissioned by First Minister Mark Drakeford in July in response to the death of George Floyd and the Black Lives Matter protests.Published yesterday, the audit was led by Gaynor Legall, and shows the slave trade was embedded in the Welsh economy and society and reflected in many statues, street and building names today.It identied  monuments, buildings or street names, located in all parts of Wales, which commemorate people who were directly involved with the slavery and the slave trade or opposed its abolition.The Vale council is carrying out its own review, with a deadline for suggested commemorations to be reviewed set for January .Hilary Brown, co-chairman of Stand Up To Racism Vale, which has been invited on the councilrsquos task board to discuss links to slavery in the region, said: ldquoItrsquos important to undertake an audit evenit is decided that no street or building names in the Vale should be removed. and Hilary Brown at a protest calling for a review" alt"Penarth Times: Vale protesters Bianca Aliand Hilary Brown at a protest calling for a review" class"editor-image"Vale protesters Bianca Aliand Hilary Brown at a protest calling for a reviewldquoWe feel it is important to teach everyone about the history of these names, and to tell the stories of how these names came to be. A separate discussion to that is what needs to be doneit is decided these names should not have been given in the first place.ldquoI would like to see the findings of the Welsh Government audit properly shared with the Vale council, prior to consultation with us.ldquoWe havenrsquot heard from the Vale council at all on this. We are waiting with baited breath for that to happen.Resident Nick Schroeter welcomed the findings of the review, saying: ldquoWe are talking about things that happened hundreds of years ago, and slavery is such a erse topic and has happened throughout history.ldquoIrsquom not saying itrsquos right, but I do believe we need to learn from it and move on.Stand Up To Racism protesters outside the Civic Offices, Barry, over the Valersquos connections to slaveryldquoEventhese road names were changed, people will still call them the same names. I feel especially during a pandemic these reviews are a waste of resources.Dinas resident Richard Winder added: ldquoThis generation needs to be aware of this stain on our history and to know of the terrible conditions on the slave ships and in the plantations, and also of the inhumanity of the gang masters and of the unimaginable obscenities of the punishments handed out.ldquoIf this means changing street names, moving statues, or educating as to how the money to build many of our great historic houses came from, then so be it.ldquoWe cannot change the past but we have the opportunity to do something positive to empathise with the feelings of our fellow countrymen, many of whom will have a history of slavery in their family long ago.The Vale council has been contacted for a response. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: covid vaccine rolled across wales coming days
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThis morning it was announced the Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agencyhad authorised the first vaccine as safe and effective on the basis of detailed independent expert review of evidence from large scale clinical trials.The Pfizer Biontech vaccine has become the first to receive MHRA clearance in the UK and  million doses of the vaccine will shortly be available for delivery across the UK, with Wales getting its allocation based on population.Approval from the MHRA is the first step of Walesrsquo roll-out plan, which has seen preparations on-going since May.There are still a number of stages which need to happen before the vaccine reaches those in highest need and is ready for use, but this process is expected to happen over the next week.These stages includeThe Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisationfinalising and publishing their guidance for the whole of the UKFinalising training materials for staff and patient information leafletsTraining of experienced immunisers for this particular vaccineFinal legal frameworks to allow registered health professionals to administer the vaccine to patients need to be authorised by each Health Board in Wales.The vaccine - which needs to be administered in two doses - will initially be prioritised and available for those aged  and over, care home staff and residents and those working within health and social care.As further supplies become available and additional vaccines receive MHRA approval, a staged approach will see other groups offered the vaccine, based on risk of serious complications and deaths.Iniduals in the priority groups for a Covid- vaccine will receive an invitation from their employer or health board, providing information about the vaccines, telling them where to go and what to do on the day of their appointment.People are urged to wait to be invited, and not to ask their pharmacist or GP.The chief medical officer for Wales, Dr Frank Atherton, said: ldquoIt is fantastic to finally say that the first Covid- vaccine has been given the green light."We know now that we have a safe and effective vaccine for use across the UK - this is the positive news I and so many across the country have been waiting for.ldquoAll our NHS organisations across Wales have embraced the challenge presented to them and are at the advanced stages of planning for the arrival of a vaccine."We have tested distribution and storage arrangements to ensure we can get vaccine safely to every part of Wales.ldquoTherersquos still a few stages we need to work through but once all these safeguards are in place, vaccination can begin."There will only be relatively small amounts of the vaccine at first, those who have been advised as most needing the vaccine first, through approved delivery mechanisms."A full announcement around the timetable for roll-out in Wales will follow in the next few days.The effects of the vaccine may not be seen nationally for many months and the advice on keeping Wales safe remains the same for everyone, warned the first minister.Mark Drakeford said: "Todayrsquos news is a small glimmer of light at the end of what has been a long and dark tunnel.ldquoWe know some people within our communities are much more at risk than others from the serious complications of Covid-, which is why the new vaccine is being prioritised to protect them first.ldquoWhilst these first doses are given at fixed sites and occupational settings, and to protect our NHS and social care services, we must all continue to do our bit to prevent the spread of coronavirus: regular hand washing, social distancing, and wearing a face covering where required to protect yourself and others.Pfizer Biontech vaccine needs to be stored at ultra-low temperatures. These centres have already been decided by health boards and are in the process of being prepared.The development process for coronavirus vaccines has been as stringent as any other but the process in the face of the pandemic has been sped up by prompt, world-wide funding and a reduction in paperwork.Theof the trials have not been shortened, and the usual safety measures remain in place.The vaccine will not be mandatory and people will be able to choose whether they take up the vaccine or not.Information will be provided to people before vaccination to reassure them about patient safety and robust consent processes will be in place.Vice-chairman of the Covid- Vaccine Programme Board, Richard Roberts from Public Health Wales, said: ldquoIt is a signicant achievement that only  months after WHOannounced the global pandemic that we now have the first safe and effective vaccine available for use in Wales, and other vaccines to follow."Everyone has been preparing for months to deliver the Covid- vaccine programme, and it is very exciting that we will be able to begin, once the final steps have been put in place so that the programme can be delivered safely. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe news comes after new coronavirus restrictions were announced on Monday.Pubs, restaurants and cafes will be banned from selling alcohol from Friday and will be unable to open to customers beyond pm.Announcing the news first minister Mark Drakeford said the new restrictions will help tackle a rise in coronavirus cases.But publicans reacted in unison to the news to condemn the latest rule changes, saying many pubs and bars will be left with almost nothing when the financial year comes to an end in the spring, and loans have to be repaidcoinciding with the end of the furlough scheme.David Cole, part owner of Gin  at Victoria Road, said he was expecting restrictionsbut says he was stunned at the severity of the new rules.David ColeldquoI was anticipating they would allow us to open until pm and serve alcohol, which would have hurt us but at least it would have been something ndash but these restrictions mean we canrsquot operate at all after Friday until theyrsquore lted, said Mr Cole.ldquoWe would be lucky to get one customer a day.Mr Drakeford said firms hit by the restrictions would be offered poundm in support which he claimed was "the most generous package" anywhere in the UK.Mr Cole added: ldquoIrsquom very concerned we will lose signicant revenue ndash itrsquos undoubtedly the busiest time of the year for us.ldquoI understand there needs to be restrictions, but in the lead up to Christmas are we really expecting these changes will make people stop socialising ldquoI think it will increase the numbers of illegal gatherings, and therersquoll be no one around to remind people to socially distance. I wouldnrsquot be surprised to see a spike in cases as a result of this decision.All pub and bar owners that spoke to the Penarth Times said they are concerned about what happens after the next review on December , with the majority saying they do not believe pubs will be able to serve alcohol until January.Health minister Vaughan Gething said he understood why companies in the industry are upset, but admitted there is "no perfect balance" between protecting public health and businesses.Health minister Vaughan GethingBut Brains CEO Alistair Darby told the Penarth Times he feels the government has got the balance wrong.Brains pubs including the Windsor and the Star Inn in Dinas Powys will close on Friday.ldquo, people have come through our doors since the start of the pandemic ndash seven staff members have tested positive in that time and test and trace have contacted us five times, said Mr Darby.ldquoI wonrsquot question the science behind the government decision, but it seems to me wersquove shown what wersquove done has worked.ldquoWersquove worked tirelessly to make sure people are as safe as possible in our pubs, and people have been safe. Our findings show that.ldquoThe scarring effect this will have on the economy will be brutal and long drawn out. We have already been operating at a  per cent deficit compared to .ldquoWersquore a business that is well run, looks after its workers, pays its taxes and contributes a lot to the economy to support the NHS.ldquoIrsquom aware there has to be a balance. But itrsquos imperative we donrsquot crush our economy in the process. I think this time that balance has not been achieved.John Bassett, who owns The Golden Lion on Glebe Street which will also be closed, said: ldquoAre they going to say we can open for Christmas after this  Irsquod be surprised.John BassettldquoIrsquom resigned to an awful period financially ndash my only focus now is to try and keep all  of my staff. I havenrsquot laid any of my staff off yet, and donrsquot intend to, but this is really becoming testing for us now.ldquoYet again we received hardly any notice before this comes into effect. I would question how the whole industry has been treated throughout this period.ldquoMark Drakeford says he talks to stakeholders ndash yet I know nobody who has ever had a conversation with a representative of the Welsh Government on this issue.Natasha Rees, new landlady at St Fagans on Windsor Road, has worked tirelessly since she took the pub over in the autumn to make it a family friendly place. Itrsquos a big blow for me but I feel mostly for them .ldquoMost of them come to have a chat, not to drink, but the reality is we wonrsquot be able to sell enough soft drinks to warrant staying open.The Railway Hotel also confirmed it will be closing until further notice.The Welsh Government were contacted for further comment but failed to respond.The Christmas edition of Gin s Penarth Gin is a small batch edition they have produced for the festive season. title: ministers outline new covid  regulations
story: MINISTERS have outlined a package of measures agreed by the Executive that will come into effect at the end of the two week circuit breaker. Shops, hairdressers, restaurants, places of worship and hotels are among the places that will be able to re-open from December . Pubs selling drink onlywill remain closed and an additional financial package will be put in place. The Executive has also agreed Christmas household bubbling arrangements from December -. Three households will be able to come together for this period in domestic settings, outdoor public spaces and places of worship. One of the households will be able to include their existing household bubble. First Minister Arlene Foster said: “Through our collective efforts over recent weeks we gained enough space in the transmission of the virus to relax a signicant number of restrictions, including the opening-up of non-essential retail, close contact services, sport and leisure activities and our places of worship at the end of next week. “These decisions will give families, businesses and employees some much-needed certainty and comfort in the run-up to Christmas and beyond. “This is a special time of the year and we want to support people to have a good Christmas, but also a safe one. “Signicant work has been completed with business sectors, faith groups, local government and police on new mitigation measures to reduce the risk of transmission. “I urge everyone to be Covid-aware and to make careful and sensible decisions when out and about or mixing with others. We need to make sure we continue doing all we can to protect ourselves and our loved ones.” Deputy First Minister Michelle O’Neill said: “The Executive wants to give people as much notice as possible on what the situation will look like from next Friday when the current circuit breaker comes to an end. “We have given detailed consideration to which restrictions need tobe maintained, and what we can open up, in light of the scientic and medical advice. “A package of measures that will see signicant relaxations to the current restrictions has been agreed, with maximum mitigations in place to minimise risks to the greatest extent possible. An additional support package will be put in place for traditional drink-only pubs that unfortunately will not be able to reopen at this time. “We appreciate how important Christmas time is for many families and the Executive has agreed arrangements that will allow families and friends to come together in a limited way between  and  December. “It’s important for people to understand that with any increased contact comes increased risk. Everyone needs to think very carefully about the risks posed to them, and their loved ones, by coming together over the Christmas period, particularly to those who are vulnerable. Some may choose not to form a Christmas bubble but for those who do, we encourage them to keep their bubbles small and limit the numbers of people gathering, as much as possible.”  addthis,     Leave
